bibl.title: Letter fragment to Mabel H. Lazear, January 10, 1928

div1.p: The writer reports that an effort is underway to increase the annuities of the yellow fever investigators, volunteers, and their relatives.

div1.head: Letter fragment to Mabel H. Lazear, January 10, 1928
div1.p:
This long delay in answering your good letter must seem to you in-
excusable. You will pardon it, I am sure, when I tell you that I had a
long four months of nervous exhaustion. I get so interested in this
campaign to secure something like adequate recognition for those of you
who have suffered such neglect all these years that I cannot seem to
let go, until Nature steps in and calls a halt. Its was nothing serious,
all I needed was a rest--and perhaps to give my friends a rest! I am
all right now with the exception of a bad cold.

You will see by the enclosures that we have not been idle all these
weeks. I had a very interesting talk with Mr. Mead last Saturday. He
told me how the Merchants' Association became interested in securing the
annuities for you, Mrs. Reed, Mrs. Carroll and the Kissingers, and he
promises all the help his organization can give in this new endeavor of
which he heartily approves. He suggested that I see the Secretary of
the New York Academy of Medicine, for they gave their help in the dis-
couraging, but finally successful, campaign at Washington. Dr. Fosdick
and the other members of our wonderful Citizens' Committee are glad to
continue until we get what we are working for.

We expect the bill for the increased annuities and for the Congress-
ional medals will be introduced in the Senate by Senator Copeland of
New York and by Congressman Merritt of Connecticut. Both are “solD” to
the plan. The Bronx Home News will print and give to us 2000 copies of
the enclosed story (I trust it contains nothing which you would disap-
prove of). The OUTLOOK will let us have 2000 copies of their four strong
editorials. I am hoping the American Museum of Natural History will
print a similar number of copies of my lecture (a copy of which I sent
you, I believe) together with illustrations. The White Plains Chamber of
Commerce is sending a letter (much like the enclosed editorial which ap-
peared in the White Plains Reporter) to every Chamber of Commerce in the
United States. Something ought to result before Congress adjourns. Can
we not get some organizations out there to do something to insure action
among the western members of Congress?
Please give my regards to your son and daughter.

closer.seg:
P. S. It seems very probable that the American Museum will print 5000
copies of the lecture I am to give in their large auditorium on February
9th. 2000 of these copies will be used with the other material mentioned
above for our campaign. The other copies will be used for study in the
City High Schools. They plan to include the 35 illustrations from my
lantern slides. President H. F. Osborn of the Museum, who has been re-
cently elected President of the American Association for the Advancement
of Science will do all he can to bring this matter to the attention of
the scientists of the country.
